2.text:
Marie:              Hey it’s
Marie Forleo and you are watching MarieTV,

8.text:
the place to be to create a business and life
you love. I’ve got a question for you. Do

11.text:
you ever feel like you self sabotage around
money? Ever wonder if you have some limiting

17.text:
beliefs from childhood that are holding you?
Whether you’ve got mountains of debt or

22.text:
you just can't seem to get ahead? Most of
us have a next financial level that we would

27.text:
love to get to. If that sounds like you, you
are in for a treat today because you're going

31.text:
to learn about four money beliefs that may
be holding you back and how to fix them.

37.text:
Kate Northrup is the bestselling author of
Money: A Lost Story, Untangle your Financial

41.text:
Woes and Create the Life You Really Want.
She created financial freedom for herself

46.text:
at the age of 28 through building a team of
more than 1,000 wellness entrepreneurs in

50.text:
the network marketing industry. Her philosophy
is that if you free yourself financial, you

55.text:
can be fully present to your purpose on the
planet. She's been featured on the Today Show,

59.text: the Huffington Post, Glamour and more.

62.text:
Miss Kate Northrup, thank you so much for
being on MarieTV.

66.text:
Kate:           Thank you so much
for having me.

68.text:
Marie:                     I
just got to say once again. Money: A Love

71.text:
Story, amazing book by Kate. If you don’t
have it, go out and get it ASAP.

78.text:
Lets talk money because we’ve been friends
for years and I love talking about money.

83.text:
I think it’s an amazing topic, it’s an
integral part of our lives and I'm really

87.text:
passionate about it. So many people, especially
this time in the world, so many people are

93.text:
struggling financially and a lot of people
aren’t, so there's really a possibility

97.text:
for us all to get to that next level. I'm
curious. Why are you so passionate about this

103.text:
Kate:           I really see money
as a tool for people to be able to show up

106.text:
in a bigger way. Money is neither negative
nor positive; it just is a tool for us to

111.text:
make change. If we've got a lot of financial
chaos going on, we’re worried about how

115.text:
am I going to put food on the table, how am
I going to pay the rent, where's the mortgage

119.text:
going to come from. That takes up a lot of
bandwidth, a lot of our creative bandwidth,

123.text:
a lot of our power bandwidth and we’re not
able to show up in the same way as if our

129.text:
financial lives were in order and taken care
so that we could then come over here and do

134.text:
the things that are higher leveraged that
are really of service. Getting it together

139.text:
financially is really just a vehicle for being
able to show up more fully in your purpose.

144.text:
Marie:                     I
agree with that 100%. You know my story where

148.text:
I started off thousands and thousands and
thousands of dollars in debt and it sucked;

154.text:
it was really hard to think about how to create
everything when I was “am I going to have

158.text:
enough to pay rent or to eat” or anything
like that. I know for you, you’ve come a

164.text:
very far way in a short couple of years, personally
financially. Can you tell us a little bit

170.text:
about your story and how big of a change you’ve
made in these past couple of years?

174.text:
Kate:           Sure. I moved to
New York when I was 22 and I promptly got

178.text:
myself into about $20,000 worth of credit
card debt, probably a little bit more at some

182.text:
points, and I didn’t even know that that
was the number until several years in because

189.text:
I had my head dipped so deeply in the sand
avoiding looking at it. I was just like “I’ll

194.text:
just spend and spend” and they were on things
that were business stuff and courses; it’s

201.text:
not like I had a closet full of Jimmy Choos,
but it was still way beyond my means. I noticed

207.text:
I was so unconscious about money and I was
so avoidant and I was so scared to look at

213.text:
Marie:                     I
have a question for you. Would you get bills

216.text:
that they would come in and you just wouldn’t
open them and you'd stick them in a drawer?

221.text:
Kate:           Yeah. I knew what
my minimum was on every card and I had a lot

226.text:
of them, so it was like this shell game where
I would just pay a little more than the minimum

231.text:
which made me feel like I'm making a little
progress, but I really wasn’t and I was

234.text:
just in this quagmire and I felt really unauthentic
because I was out running a business, I was

239.text:
teaching women about different streams of
income and thinking in new ways about cash

245.text:
flows, but behind the scenes, I had all this
financial chaos and I knew I wasn’t taking

249.text:
responsibility for it. For the whole thing,
it felt really awful and it was that way around

257.text:
the time that you and I met and I was hiding
it.

261.text:
Marie:                     Really?
That’s so interesting. You were hiding it

265.text:
from most of the world publically and so how
long did it take for you to reach that breaking

270.text:
point where you were like, “I've had enough,
I got to handle this, I can't do this anymore,

277.text:
Kate:           It was about four
years. I always was a good earner so it was

283.text:
never like I couldn’t eat or anything. I
could always just keep me little nose above

289.text:
the surface so I could still breathe and it
was about four years that I finally sat myself

297.text:
down and said “You know what? Enough is
enough,” and I realized that I was holding

302.text:
myself back from being able to be in my full
ability to make change in the world by being

307.text:
in financial chaos. I knew that was a way
I was keeping myself small and so I just finally

313.text: decided to do something about it.

314.text:
Marie:                     Let’s
fast forward. What are the numbers? How much

317.text:
debt did you get yourself out of and how fast
did you do it?

320.text:
Kate:           When I really made
some significant changes in my life, I was

323.text:
in about $20,000 and six months later, I had
paid it all off basically in one fell swoop

332.text:
and doubled my income and doubled my savings
and it was amazing what happened when I just

338.text:
got my rear in gear and made some critical
mindset shifts which we’re going to talk

342.text:
about today and it all worked out. It’s
kind of shocking.

347.text:
Marie:                     Isn’t
it amazing when that happens and when you

350.text:
actually tell the truth and stop lying? It
is so huge. I know it can feel so scary. It’s

358.text:
not about money but back in my early 20s when
I was engaged to be married to someone that

362.text:
I knew I wasn’t going to married, but I
was terrified of breaking it off because our

369.text:
finances were co-mingled and I was just so
scared. I only lasted about six months in

373.text:
a lie but living that lie, I think we've all
experienced that on some level where you know

378.text:
something is not right, you're hiding something
big but you don’t have the courage quite

384.text:
I love this topic because we’re going to
dive into these money beliefs; they're almost

388.text:
like money lies that we’re telling ourselves,
and if you could just tell yourself the truth,

393.text:
there's this incredible opening that can happen
and literally your whole life really can change

398.text: just by changing something on the inside.

400.text:
Kate:           And fast. It doesn’t
have to take a long time.

403.text:
Marie:                     I've
had some stories from clients, from friends

407.text:
and people that we've had some tough money
conversations, not tough between us personally,

411.text:
but just being there and supporting them through
it and watching how quickly things can turn

416.text:
around. I've had some people that have been
in $100,000 or $200,000 in debt, even if that

421.text:
number doesn’t go away as quickly as yours
did, it goes down really fast but more importantly

427.text: who they are in the world changes significantly.

430.text:
Kate:           That’s the whole
point; it’s not about the money.

433.text:
Marie:                     It’s
not about the money and it is about the money.

438.text:
Let’s get into it. You say we’re going
to focus on four beliefs today and the first

443.text:
one that hold us back is someone else should
or will do this for me.

447.text:
Kate:           We take our financial
power and we just give it to somebody else.

452.text:
It’s so much easier to just say “will
you just do this for me” or “hey boss,

457.text:
can you just do this for me” or “hey prince
charming, future husband who hasn’t showed

462.text:
up yet, he’ll probably take care of it for
me,” so I’ll just bide my time and keep

465.text:
being irresponsible until that point. For
me it was that I hoped that my mom would just

470.text:
take care of it for me someday. It’s so
embarrassing to even just say that right now

475.text:
but it’s true; I wrote about it in my book
so it’s out there.

480.text:
That is symptomatic of us really feeling like
we’re not enough to do it and it’s just

486.text:
saying “this is too scary, I don’t have
what it takes, I'm not smart enough,” and

491.text:
so we wait and we never turn on our full potential
because we’re hoping somebody else will

497.text: swoop in at some point and save us.

499.text:
Marie:                     It’s
a big one. There's certainly been areas in

502.text:
my life where I was thinking that someone
else was going to handle it for me and I'm

506.text:
pretty sure money was it back in the day and
now it almost feels like a different human

510.text:
being that used to think that way, but it
is a big one.

517.text:
Belief number two: I'm not good with money.
This is a big one.

522.text:
Kate:           This is a really
big one. Have you ever seen a baby be born

526.text: and be able to talk and walk?

530.text:
Kate:           But that pretty much
never happens. We've all learned the skills

535.text:
we have and so to think like you're just not
good with money is holding you back. Our beliefs

543.text:
become our actions, we act in accordance with
what our beliefs are and then our actions

547.text:
obviously create our results. That’s just
kind of a basic equation for life and when

552.text:
we think I'm not good with money, we’re
setting ourselves up for failure and we actually

557.text:
avoid taking financial steps because we have
that thought.

561.text:
Instead you can take really small actions
to start to build your confidence, and the

566.text:
one that I did, again I was really pretty
remedial with this, so when I started off,

570.text:
I was like “I just am going to check my
bank account balance everyday,” and when

574.text:
I do that, I'm going to give some gratitude
for the ways my life is abundant. I knew if

578.text:
I could just check in with money daily and
start being in that relationship and paying

582.text:
attention to it, it would be powerful. When
I started doing that every day I set a little

586.text:
Google calendar alarm, 8:30 am, ‘check your
bank account balance.’ My income increased

592.text:
and I stopped spending more than I made. It
was just like paying attention pays off and

598.text:
I started to be better and better with money
because I was paying attention to it.

602.text:
Marie:                     I
love that. Also, the things that we tell ourselves,

605.text:
we joke around a lot about it here on MarieTV.
There are some times where we’re shooting

610.text:
an episode and literally I'm flubbing this
line that I really want to get across again

615.text:
and again and we’re all joking and every
explicative comes out, and I say “I got

621.text:
this.” I tell myself “I got this,” and
wouldn’t you know nine times out of ten,

626.text:
I'm like “bam” and I get it and I deliver
that line. It’s the same thing with “I'm

631.text:
not good with money.” If you tell yourself
you're not good with money, you're never going

635.text:
to take the steps to do anything about it
and it’s almost like you just got blinders

639.text: on and you're never going to take them off.

642.text:
I love that simple step of just checking in
daily and the other thing I like about it

647.text:
is it can remove the fear. I know for me there
was a time when opening my checkbook was really

653.text:
scary and it actually produced physical sensations
of wanting to throw up because there wasn’t

661.text:
enough in there, at least that’s the story
I told myself. There was actually enough in

666.text:
there because here I am, I didn’t disintegrate
and I wasn’t getting taken off to jail or

671.text: something, but that was the feeling.

675.text:
Kate:           We can train ourselves
like Pavlov’s dog to spend that time with

679.text:
our bank account and look at it and then automatically
say, “I'm going to name three things in

685.text:
my life that I'm grateful for that feel abundant.”
You're training and rewiring your brain so

690.text:
that you're associating looking at your money
with feeling good.

693.text:
Marie:                     I
love that. Money belief number three: people

697.text:
with money are greedy or it’s not spiritual
to have money.

702.text:
Kate:           I know that this
is one you actually covered with Marianne

705.text:
Williams in your audio, which was so fantastic.
When we have a judgment against somebody for

714.text:
having something and it’s very common with
money, there's this whole lack mentality of

718.text:
rich people are greedy, they’ve stepped
on other people to get there or something.

722.text:
First of all that’s assumption. We never
know really how people got where they're at

727.text:
and chances are pretty good that they worked
hard to get there and they deserve it because

731.text: of the time they’ve put in.

733.text:
When we judge them, automatically our subconscious
mind will never allow us to have the abundance

739.text:
or prosperity that we want if we’re judging
other people for having it. Why would it let

743.text:
us be the evil person that we’re saying
they're bad because they have money or they're

756.text:
Anytime that comes up, and also, anytime it
comes up “it’s not spiritual to be rich

763.text:
or to have money,” money is a stand in for
what we value. If somebody wants something

770.text:
that you offer, like B-School for example,
and they value it according to the amount

775.text:
that it costs, that’s a service. That’s
an exchange of value for value that’s tremendous

781.text:
and the value they're receiving in their life
is huge and then you get to receive that in

785.text:
exchange. That’s all that money is; just
trading value for value. When we add value

790.text:
to somebody else’s life, to me that’s
a spiritual act to say, “I see that you

795.text:
have a need and I have something I can help
you with” then to receive an exchange for

800.text:
that is how it should be. That is the flow,
so if we start to see money as a means of

806.text:
value exchange and as a means of how can I
look at the world and say where can I add

811.text:
value, where can I help somebody, then the
whole thing begins to be rewired and we realize,

817.text:
“I will become more prosperous to the degree
that I am able to add value to somebody’s

822.text:
Marie:                     I
love that. That’s beautiful and I get really

825.text:
up in arms about that whole judging people
not spiritual to have money. Money belief

836.text:
Kate:           I'm not ____ enough;
it could be “I'm not smart enough, I'm not

844.text:
talented enough, I didn’t come from the
right background.” Whatever it is, it’s

848.text:
immediately taking you out of the game. Anytime
we don’t value ourselves, what ends up happening

854.text:
is when we’re out in the world, even if
we’re providing really good value, if we’re

858.text:
not seeing our worth, we’re not going to
get the value and exchange for that. No one

862.text: will value you more than you value yourself.

866.text:
We need to learn to value ourselves and you
can really practically, the whole self love

872.text: thing, when I hear about it-

873.text:
Marie:                     Do
you roll your eyes?

874.text:
Kate:           I do and I teach
it at the same time because it’s really

879.text:
important and pretty much I think the solution
to anything is loving yourself more but “how

883.text:
do I do that and what does that even mean.”
Really practically what you can do is get

889.text:
out a journal and every night for at least
21 days because that’s what studies show

893.text:
it takes to form a new habit, write in there
three things you value about yourself or three

899.text:
ways that you added value to somebody’s
life that day. You could be like “I was

908.text:
so funny today on MarieTV” or I could say
“I did a Skype interview today and I know

916.text:
I added value to whoever’s going to watch
that one.”

918.text:
Whatever it is, what we’re doing is we’re
building that muscle and training ourselves

923.text:
to notice things that we value about ourselves
and things that are valuable about us, and

930.text:
ways that we've added value to somebody else’s
life which will tune our radar in so that

933.text:
during the day, we’re seeing more opportunities
and we saying “I could add a little value

937.text:
over there, there's an opportunity there,”
and it makes us better business people and

941.text:
it makes us better humans. That’s a great
way to train yourself and write those three

945.text:
things down every day and it'll make you feel
the next day “I did something.” It’s

949.text:
a fabulous way to celebrate yourself and to
increase your value.

953.text:
Marie:                     I
have to say I love this one. Not so long ago,

957.text:
we did an episode about valuing your worth
and we were aiming that at artists and creatives,

965.text:
and it was shocking and beautiful to me and
heartbreaking at the same time to see how

972.text:
many of us struggling with that. It doesn’t
matter what level you're at. You could feel

978.text:
like you're just starting out on your financial
journey or your career journey, or you can

982.text:
be further along and there's times for me
where the little fear comes up. I love that

989.text:
suggestion also because adding value to someone’s
life could mean smiling. It could be an act

996.text:
of kindness. It can be taking a pause and
making a phone call and letting someone know

1002.text:
that you love them. It doesn’t have to necessarily
be a business transaction; it can actually

1012.text:
be really a beautiful act of kindness and
love and compassion that you put out into

1018.text:
Kate:           And the value we
receive back, the abundance we receive back

1021.text:
might be financial and it might be something
else. You and I both know that abundance is

1025.text:
a lot of different things; it’s our health,
it's our relationships, it's our peace of

1028.text:
mind. A life that’s rich and wealthy is
a lot of different things beyond your bank

1033.text:
Marie:                     Kate,
this was awesome. Thank you so much for coming.

1037.text:
What a rich discussion and hopefully we’ll
keep talking about this and we’re going

1042.text:
to keep talking about this in the comments
right now.

1045.text:
Now Kate and I have a challenge for you. What
is one money belief that’s been holding

1049.text:
you back? It doesn’t matter where you're
at on your financial journey; we've all got

1053.text:
one. What we want to hear about also besides
the money belief that’s holding you back,

1057.text:
what's one action you could take that demonstrates
you are ready for a new level of abundance

1063.text:
in your life? Tell us about it in the comments
below.

1066.text:
As always the best discussions happen after
the episode over at MarieForleo.com so go

1071.text: there and leave a comment now.

1073.text:
Did you like this video? If so, subscribe

even more resources to create a business and

from me that I only talk about in email, get

1090.text:
Stay on your game and keep going for your

1094.text:
